Award.AwardTitle: WORKSHOP: Quantitative Theories of Learning, Memory, and Prediction

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
The development of quantitative theories of learning, memory, and prediction is fundamental to understanding human cognitive processing. This workshop, to take place in Arlington VA, May 8-9, 2014, tackles a key scientific need: to integrate modern complex systems and network approaches with understanding cognitive function. Predictive models of higher order cognitive processes could inform the development of neuroprosthetics, facilitate advances in brain-computer interfaces, and assist in the construction of intervention protocols for cognitive deficits that accompany neurological disorders and psychiatric disease.


Understanding how the human brain works has emerged as a major international focus of research in the coming decade, identified as such in President Obama's State of the Union Address in February 2013 and further developed in President Obama's BRAIN initiative announced on April 2, 2013. This workshop will bring together systems neuroscientists, cognitive scientists, applied mathematicians, and theoretical physicists. The aim is to identify a set of achievable goals that integrate dynamic, quantitative theories of cognition with neuroscientific and theoretical avenues of research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
As brain imaging and manipulation technologies become increasingly sophisticated, data sets that could potentially provide new insights into human cognitive function become more plentiful. However, a critical gap lies in the development of quantitative theories of higher order cognitive functions that capitalize on these data.  The major outcome of this project was a workshop that focused on learning, memory, and prediction, which require complex, dynamic processes across large-scale distributed neural circuits. We brought together expertise in theoretical physics, computational modeling, data acquisition, and cognitive neuroscience to discuss the next frontiers in theoretical models of higher order cognitive processes. In this workshop, we outlined a handful of theoretical areas where — given appropriate levels of funding — groundbreaking advances are tractable in the 5-10 year time frame with the collaborative efforts of both theoreticians and experimentalists. The key outcome of the workshop was a coalescing of intellectual efforts around the topic of quantitative theories in learning, memory, and prediction. A second key outcome was increased lines of communication between experimentalists and theorists in this area, which have been utilized extensively over the past year. Finally, trainnees from graduate students and postdocs to young assistant professors were exposed to cutting edge ideas and existing controversies of these fields, as well as ideas for future growth.
